title: Projects
text: Here is my project 1

title: Housing Price Prediction (STAT 101A Course Project)
text:
This project applied multiple linear regression to model housing unit-area prices in Sindian District, New Taipei City, Taiwan. After using transformations, model selection, and diagnostics, our final model improved R² from ~0.58 to 0.72.



Analyzed 414 real estate observations with six predictors

Explored scatterplots, transformations, multicollinearity, and model assumptions

Applied log transformation to Y and MRT distance to stabilize variance and improve fit

Selected the final model using Adjusted R², AIC, and diagnostics





Houses newer, close to MRT, and near convenience stores had significantly higher prices.

Latitude & longitude revealed geographic price patterns across northern and eastern districts.

The final model explained 72.4% of price variation.





Data preprocessing, transformations, diagnostics

Model selection and interpretation

Presentation slides and narrative explanation





Final Paper: Download
Presentation Slides: Download

title: Lasso Regression & Federated Learning (STAT 102B Final Project)
text:
This project implemented coordinate descent Lasso and extended it into a federated learning system where three nodes trained shared models without exchanging raw data.



Implemented cyclic coordinate descent with soft-thresholding

Tuned λ via validation loss (grid search)

Found 13 overlapping predictors across nodes

Smaller datasets required stronger regularization

Sparser models generalized better





Nodes independently tuned λ

Performed U local updates, then aggregated weighted coefficients

Compared 5-update vs. 10-update synchronization

Federated model matched test accuracy of best node while reducing variance

Less frequent aggregation reduced communication at no accuracy cost





Wrote full coordinate descent implementation

Built federated synchronization loop and coefficient aggregator

Visualized convergence + coefficient shrinkage patterns

Wrote project analysis, discussion, and methodology sections





Part A Report: Download
Part B Report: Download

title: The Modulatory Effects of Music Genre and Exposure Duration on Cognitive Focus (STAT 101B Final Project)
text:
A two-factor ANOVA with blocking (age & gender) analyzed how music genre and listening duration affect sustained attention.



Significant main effects: music type (p < 0.001), duration (p = 0.013)

Significant interaction: genre × duration (p = 0.010)

Heavy metal increased attention misses, especially at 30 minutes.

Classical, Country, and Dance music maintained cognitive performance.





216 participants (multistage sampling)

Blocking by age group and gender

Tukey HSD to compare genre and duration levels

ggplot2 visualizations (interaction plots + boxplots)





Built ANOVA model & diagnostics

Created interaction and boxplot visualizations

Wrote narrative analysis and interpretation sections





Final Research Paper: Download
Presentation Slides: Download

title: ASA DataFest 2025 – Commercial Real Estate Analytics
text:
Analyzed 200K+ commercial lease records (2018–2024) from Savills to uncover post-COVID leasing trends in Manhattan’s financial sector.



Manhattan dominated U.S. office leasing volume both before and after COVID.

Class-A demand increased 50%, while B/C space lagged.

South Manhattan ZIP codes (10001, 10022) showed the highest square footage.

Availability remained high (15–20%), giving tenants leverage.

Hybrid work reduced seating needs but intensified “flight-to-quality.”





Cleaned and analyzed 200K+ leasing records

Visualized geographic clustering, Class-A trends, and occupancy correlations

Co-developed the narrative, insights, and final presentation





Presentation Slides: Download

title: Australia Bushfires Digital Humanities Project (DH 101 Final Project)
text:
Digital Humanities 101 Final — Summer 2025
A full web-based mini-site analyzing the 2019–2020 Australian bushfires using NASA FIRMS & MODIS fire datasets.
Live Website: https://firestorm.humspace.ucla.edu/



Interactive geospatial fire map

Timeline of major fire events

MODIS/NASA-based charts on fire spread & intensity

Narrative analysis of environmental + social impacts

Data critique discussing limitations & representational gaps





Fire activity peaked during late 2019–early 2020

Southeastern Australia showed extreme density and severity

Climate anomalies (drought, heat) amplified risk

Human communities experienced disparate impacts based on geography





Processed fire-archive datasets (NASA/MODIS)

Built interactive map, timeline, and statistical visualizations

Wrote narrative sections, visualization explanations, and data critique

Connected data findings to climate change + social vulnerability





Public mini-site hosted on HumSpace
